author: kai-h
body:
Steps to reproduce
------------------
Install PowerShell on macOS
Open a new PowerShell instance
Do something that causes text to be output to the terminal
Copy and paste this text into somewhere else, e.g. a text editor or an email.
There is extraneous whitespace at the end of every line to pad it out to the width of my Terminal window, which is by default 80 columns.

Expected behavior
-----------------
It is expected that the text output in the Terminal will not have extra whitespace at the end of each and every line.

Actual behavior
---------------
Output is padded to the width of the Terminal window.
e.g. if you look at the output for $PSVersionTable below, copy and paste it into a text editor and you will notice that every line is 150 characters long, padded out with the space character. My Terminal window was 150 characters wide so that it could fit in the output for the OS line without truncating it.

Environment data
----------------
```
PS /Users/kai> $PSVersionTable                                                                                                                        

Name                           Value                                                                                                                 
----                           -----                                                                                                                 
PSVersion                      6.0.0-rc                                                                                                              
PSEdition                      Core

Platform                       Unix                                                                                                                  
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0...}

```

comments.author: mklement0
comments.body:
This behavior is by (perhaps unfortunate) design: 

PowerShell's formatting system _always_ produces lines right-padded to the (implied or explicitly specified) output width with spaces.

It is only when you copy directly from a Windows _console window_ that _it_ extends you the (debatable) courtesy of trimming the trailing spaces (the macOS terminal program doesn't do that, and neither does Ubuntu's default terminal program, for instance).

You can verify the behavior by piping to `clip` on Windows as opposed to manually copying in the console window:

```powershell
Get-Item / | clip  # text on clipboard will have trailing spaces
```

comments.author: mklement0
comments.body:
@kai-h: 

The padding seems to happen only for types for which type-specific output formatting was _explicitly_ defined, as described in `Get-Help about_Format.ps1xml`, and (as @SteveL-MSFT  points out below) when a _table view_ is being rendered (whether implicitly or via `Format-Table`).

To illustrate the difference (assume an 80-column terminal):

```powershell
# The type of $PSVersionTable derives from [hashtable], which has explicit formatting
# data associated with it and defaults to table view:
# -> PADDING 
# All nonempty lines are padded to the output width, which defaults to the terminal width.
> $PSVersionTable | Out-String -Stream | % Length
0
80
80
80
80
80
80
80
80
80
80
80
0
0


# [System.Management.Automation.Host.KeyInfo], as returned by `$host.ui.RawUI.ReadKey()`,
# has NO formatting definitions associated with it.
# -> NO padding.
> [System.Management.Automation.Host.KeyInfo]::new(65, 'A', 0, $True) | Out-String -Stream | % Length
0
48
48
48
0
0
```

Normally you could use `Get-FormatData <type-name>` to check if a given type has associated formatting data, but that is currently broken - see #4237 and #4235.

comments.author: SteveL-MSFT
comments.body: This appears to be `by design`.  Any table view has padding.  Any non-table view, I made a PR (merged awhile back) to remove padding and linebreaks.

comments.author: kai-h
comments.body:
Following "The law of least surprise" for how things generally should work, if you're getting plain text output, it should not be padded to some arbitrary width that depends on the size of your Terminal window. If it's padded (and it probably shouldn't be) it would possibly be better to be padded to a fixed width, dependent on the width of the output table.
Or, if you're not recolouring the output, it shouldn't be padded at all.
Or somehow have the trailing spaces trimmed when copying to the clipboard, however this may be out of your control and depend more on the Terminal app in use.

comments.author: SteveL-MSFT
comments.body:
For Tables, it seems that there should be no reason for the trailing padding.  A new line should be sufficient.  This isn't macOS specific, it repros on Linux as well (the code is the same on all platforms).  I think Windows clipboard may be doing something to trim trailing whitespace...

I'll look into this as I've made changes to this code previously and think it should be a small change (although not entirely sure of the side effects...)

comments.author: iSazonov
comments.body: If console background is black and we output a table with green background then we can not trim trailing whitespace - we lost green background.

comments.author: mklement0
comments.body:
>  I think Windows clipboard may be doing something

It's actually the _console window_ that does it (copying directly out of a window) - if you pipe to `clip.exe` in order to copy to the clipboard, you do get the padding.

comments.author: SteveL-MSFT
comments.body: @iSazonov I think we should support cells in the table having a background, but not the entire table.  Alternatively, if we want to support colored background, then we can special case that to preserve padding.
